Create users and groups, and define policies that manage
access to Control Center applications.
info.title: Akamai: Identity and Access Management API

get.description: Returns details about your API client.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity and Access Management API

parameters.description: For customers who manage more than one account, this [runs the operation from another account](https://techdocs.akamai.com/developer/docs/manage-many-accounts-with-one-api-client). The Identity and Access Management API provides a [list of available account switch keys](https://techdocs.akamai.com/iam-api/reference/get-client-account-switch-keys).
parameters.name: accountSwitchKey

schema.description: This object encapsulates the response schema for creating API client.

accessToken.description: Part of the client secret that identifies your API client and lets you access applications and resources. Tokens are unique per client.

actions.description: Encapsulates actions the API client may perform.

delete.description: When enabled, the API client can be deleted.

deactivateAll.description: When enabled, all credentials of the API client can be deactivated.

edit.description: When enabled, the API client can be updated.

editApis.description: When enabled, the `apis` of the API client can be updated.

editAuth.description: When enabled, the `groups` or `apis` of the API client can be updated.

editGroups.description: When enabled, the `groups` of the API client can be updated.

editSwitchAccount.description: When enabled, the API client option to manage many accounts can be updated.

lock.description: When enabled, the API client can be locked if it's currently unlocked.

transfer.description: When enabled, the API client can be transferred to a new owner.

unlock.description: When enabled, the API client can be unlocked if it's currently locked.

activeCredentialCount.description: Number of credentials active for the API client.

allAccessibleApis.description: Indicates if the API client has access to a full set of available APIs. Note there's a limit of 99 API services for each client. Clients that make calls to URLs from the 100th service get a 403 error.

allowAccountSwitch.description: If you can use the API client to manage more than one account.

apis.description: Lists APIs you'd like to use. It's a specific set of accessible APIs only when `allAccessibleApis` is disabled.

apiId.description: A unique identifier for each API.

apiName.description: The name of an API, like Diagnostic Tools, or Identity Management: API.

documentationUrl.description: Link to more information about the API.

endPoint.description: The endpoint to access a API.

grantScope.description: The level of access you give to an API client on a per API basis.

baseURL.description: The base URL for the service.

ccuParams.description: Additional data needed to configure the client for access to CCU API in `apis`.

purgeByCacheTag.description: When enabled, the API client can purge content by cache tag.

purgeByCpcode.description: When enabled, the API client can purge content by CP code.

purgeCpcodes.description: Lists all CP codes that your API client is allowed to purge.

clientId.description: Unique identifier for an API client.

createdBy.description: The user who created the API client.

createdDate.description: ISO 8601 timestamp indicating when the API client was created.

actions.description: Encapsulates the different ways you can edit an API client, including changing its owner, accessing rights to Control Center, or deleting it.

delete.description: When enabled, the credential can be deleted.

activate.description: When enabled, the credential can be activated.

deactivate.description: When enabled, the credential can be deactivated.

editDescription.description: When enabled, credential's description can be edited.

editExpiration.description: When enabled, credential's expiration date can be updated.

createdOn.description: ISO 8601 timestamp indicating when credentials were created.

credentialId.description: A unique identifier for each credential.

description.description: A descriptive label for the client.

expiresOn.description: ISO 8601 timestamp indicating when the credential expire. By default, two years from the creation date.

status.description: Indicates whether the credential can be used. `ACTIVE` means the credential can be used. `INACTIVE` means the credential isn't active and can't be used, and `DELETED` means the credential no longer exists.

groups.description: The groups an API client can access.

items.description: The groups an API client can access.

groupId.description: A unique identifier for each group.

isBlocked.description: If `true`, the API client has access to the group's parent, but can't access the child group.

parentGroupId.description: The unique identifier for the parent group within the group tree. If you're viewing group info for a root-level group, you may not see this member.

roleDescription.description: The human-readable description for a role.

roleId.description: A unique identifier for each role.

subGroups.description: Children of the parent group, represented as an array of groups. Permissions cascade downward from parent to child unless the child group's `isBlocked` is `true`.

locked.description: When enabled, you can lock the client to prevent anyone from using it to access services on Control Center.

notificationList.description: List of email addresses to notify of any expiring credentials.

serviceProviderId.description: A unique identifier for a service provider.

uiIdentityId.description: The unique identifier of the user the API client is being created for.

uiUserName.description: The human-readable username of the person who owns the API client.

useOwnerGroups.description: When enabled, grants the client the same group access as the owner. Otherwise access is limited to the groups specified in `groups`.

200.description: The response returns the API client.

get.description: The response object contains the `accountSwitchKeys` and account names you can access based on the permissions of your API client. Once you have the `accountSwitchKeys`, you can make an API call to another account. To learn more, see [Manage many accounts with one API client](https://techdocs.akamai.com/developer/docs/manage-many-accounts-with-one-api-client).

parameters.name: search

parameters.description: For customers who manage more than one account, this [runs the operation from another account](https://techdocs.akamai.com/developer/docs/manage-many-accounts-with-one-api-client). The Identity and Access Management API provides a [list of available account switch keys](https://techdocs.akamai.com/iam-api/reference/get-client-account-switch-keys).
parameters.name: accountSwitchKey

schema.description: This object encapsulates a collection of contexts the client can manage.

accountName.description: The name you supply for an account.

accountSwitchKey.description: The identifier for an account other than your API client's default.

200.description: The response lists account switch keys.

post.description: Creates a new credential for your API client. Only you may create credentials for this client. Credentials are in `active` status at creation. They expire two years from their creation date. However, when the API client's permissions are based on Control Center permissions, credentials expire differently and follow the same rotation schedule listed for user passwords on those accounts. Run the [Update a credential](https://techdocs.akamai.com/iam-user-admin/reference/put-client-credential) operation to change the expiration date, description, or status. Save the values from the response, such as the `credentialID` for future use. This is the only time you'll see the client secret. Save the credential at this time to avoid the need to create a new one.

schema.description: This object encapsulates all members for the credential data structure.

createdOn.description: ISO 8601 timestamp indicating when credentials were created.

credentialId.description: A unique identifier for each credential.

description.description: Lets you add your own notes or description for your credential.

expiresOn.description: ISO 8601 timestamp indicating when the credential expire. By default, two years from the creation date.

status.description: Shows whether a credential is `ACTIVE`, `INACTIVE`, or `DELETED`. You can switch a credential's `status` between `ACTIVE` and `INACTIVE`. Note that once you change the status to `DELETED`, you've actually deleted it and it can't be reactivated.

201.description: The response returns the created credentials.

Save the values from the response, such as the `credentialID`, for future use. This is the only time you'll see the client secret. get.description: List users who would be affected if you were to move a group. Users may lose or gain access to resources depending on the roles and permissions of the new parent group. Users with a `userType` of `lostAccess` lose their access to the source group. If the `userType` is `gainAccess`, they gain access to the resources in the source group. Users who have inherited access to a group lose access to that group if it moves out of its the hierarchy that gives them those access rights. If the group moves to another parent group to which they have access, they still have access to the group you move. Likewise, when a group is moved to its new location, users who inherit their access rights from the new parent group gain access to the resources in the group you move.

isCloneable.description: If `true`, an administrator can create a new user with the same permissions as this user.

resetPassword.description: Allows an administrator to send a user a password by email or see a one-time token.

thirdPartyAccess.description: Allows the administrator to manage extended access.

authGrants.description: A user's role assignments, per group. If you provide this member in a POST request, don't include the `cloneFrom` member in the request too.

items.description: A user's role assignments, per group. If you provide this member in a POST request, don't include the `cloneFrom` member in the request too.

groupId.description: A unique identifier for each group.

isBlocked.description: Indicates whether a user's access is blocked for a group.

roleId.description: A unique identifier for each role.

subGroups.description: Children of the parent group, represented as an array of groups. Permissions cascade downward from parent to child unless the child group's `isBlocked` is `true`.

contactType.description: To help characterize the user, the value can be any that are available from the [View contact types](https://techdocs.akamai.com/iam-user-admin/reference/get-common-contact-types) operation.

country.description: Part of the user's location. This can be any value available from the [View supported countries](https://techdocs.akamai.com/iam-user-admin/reference/get-common-countries) operation.

lastLoginDate.description: ISO 8601 timestamp indicating when the user last logged in.

mobilePhone.description: The user's mobile phone number, represented as a 10-digit integer within a string.

notifications.description: The notification emails the user receives for products.

options.description: The types of notification emails the user receives.

newUserNotification.description: Send emails to group administrators when new users are created.

proactive.description: Lists products for which the user receives notification emails about service issues.

upgrade.description: Lists products for which the user receives notification emails about upgrades.

enableEmailNotifications.description: Indicates if email notifications are enabled.

passwordExpiryDate.description: The date a user's password expires.

phone.description: The user's main phone number, represented as a ten-digit integer within a string.

preferredLanguage.description: The value can be any that are available from the [View languages](https://techdocs.akamai.com/iam-user-admin/reference/get-common-languages) operation.

sessionTimeOut.description: The number of seconds it takes for the user's Control Center session to time out if there hasn't been any activity. This corresponds to the `value` output of the [View timeout policies](https://techdocs.akamai.com/iam-user-admin/reference/get-common-timeout-policies) operation.

timeZone.description: The user's time zone. The value can be any that are available from the [View time zones](https://techdocs.akamai.com/iam-user-admin/reference/get-common-timezones) operation.

uiIdentityId.description: A unique identifier for a user's profile, which corresponds to a user's actual profile or client ID.

uiUserName.description: A user's `loginId`. Typically, a user's email address.

zipCode.description: The user's five-digit ZIP code, represented as a string.

200.description: The response returns the user's profile.

Users can run this operation to modify their own profile's password policy. schema.description: Encapsulates all information for a password policy.

caseDif.description: The minimum number of characters with a different case. For example, a value of 1 means at least one letter needs to be uppercase if the rest are lowercase.

maxRepeating.description: The maximum allowed number of repeating characters.

minDigits.description: The minimum number of digits in a password.

minLength.description: The minimum length of a password.

minLetters.description: The minimum number of letters in a password.

minNonAlpha.description: The minimum number of non-alphabetic characters in a password.

minReuse.description: The minimum number of previous passwords to retain to prevent password reuse.

pwclass.description: A unique identifier for a password policy.

rotateFrequency.description: The number of days a password is valid.

200.description: The response returns the password policy.

get.summary: View password policy for a user profile

put.description: Enable or disable TFA on your profile. An account administrator needs to disable TFA for you if the account is set to `enable`. If the account doesn't specify a TFA setting, you can `disable` TFA on your profile yourself. You can always set TFA to `enable` regardless of account-level settings. If you have TFA enabled, `reset` TFA clears your TFA settings and you'll be asked to set up TFA the next time you log in to Control Center.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity and Access Management API

parameters.description: __Enum__ Includes the actions you can perform for TFA on your own profile, either `enable`, `disable`, or `reset`. Don't confuse this with the `actions` parameter, which applies to the various operations that get user data.
parameters.name: action
